Tim is in Birmingham.
Hey.

Mr. V.
WOOTEN: All right.
I've been teaching bass and other string instruments in Birmingham for about the last six years now.
And a lot of my clientele come to me and they're like, I want to play like so and so, you know?
I want to learn all their riffs, all their lyrics, how to play just like them.
And it reminds me of an issue of Bass Player I had with Victor Wooten in it where he says you can't play everything just like they can.
But they can't play what you play just like you can.
So it really kind of opens them up to, you know, well, hey, maybe I need to start doing my own thing.
Maybe I can, you know, play however I want to play.
And I've really had a lot of success kind of getting people to open up and branch out even to different genres of music that they were previously closed off to.
That's - what do you, Victor, say to people who say teach me how you play so I can play like you?
Mr. V.
WOOTEN: I say exactly what this gentleman said.
But I do teach them a bit of it because that's what they came for.
Mm-hmm.
Mr.
V.
WOOTEN: I do try to give people what they come for, but at the same time, sneaking a whole lot of what I feel they need.
And so, you know, the same way we learn to talk by copying people older then us, and that's the way we progress.
That's a good starting point, which, in turn, causes me to want to get better.
I want to get better so that the younger generation has something better as their guide, you know?
So I can help that way by improving myself.
So I'll give them pieces of what I do.
But I really urge them, like I believe this teacher is doing is urging them to do things in their own way and to develop their own voice.
Tim, when you were growing up, whose licks were you stealing?
Well, I mean, I was just like a lot of the people that I came to.
I would, you know, I'd look up to people like, you know, Victor Wooten, like, you know, Stanley Clarke, like everybody.
And I would learn to play, you know, note for note exactly like they would.
Mm-hmm.
And I would get you know, at a point, I was starting to get frustrated because, like, I couldn't make it sound like they would until I kind of learned, I said, look, I need to do my own thing.
Mr. V.
WOOTEN: Right.

But it's easy to sound like you because you're already there.
So what we have to do is make that you better, and that's pretty easy.
But to sound like me or someone else, it's going to take years and years of work because it took us years and years of work to get here.
